answers.answer: You are on an awfully high dose.  Have they checked your TSH and thyroglobulin recently?I too have put on a lot of weight since my complete thyroidectomy (about 30lbs in 4 years) and can't seem to get rid of it.If your TSH and thyroglobulin are both fine (for a cancer patient - which means both should be below about 0.1) then you might ask if they can add T3 to your Synthroid or switch you to a T3 T4 product.  It might help with the energy and weight gain.Also have them check your glucose and A1C to see if you are diabetic.  There are quite a few of us who have developed diabetes since thyroid surgery which can add to, and complicate, weight gain.Best of everythingUtahmommapapillary carcinoma '03 (followup surgery '04)recurrence and RAI '06 and probably '08three sisters with papillary carcinoma

question: i HAVE HAD A OMPLETE THYROIDECTOMY due to thyroid cancer.  I am currently on synthroid 200mcg. I am considered hypo, but have had a weight gain of 50 plus pounds.  I've taken this medication since 1996 with no problems, but have dealt with up and down weight of 5 lbs.  Is there anything I can do or should be concerned about other than being overweight.  Also, I've had 3 back surgeries in a year, but am able to get around.  Please help with suggestions or answers.
title: stomACH WEIGHT
